results.title: The Road to Memphis
results.creator_credit: Richard Pearce, Robert Kenner, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. On the road - how the early bluesmen made a living was touring from town to town on what became know as ‘The Chitlin Circuit’. Still living that dream is Bobby Rush who owns a bus and takes his show on the road and has “only been outta work 6 weeks in 41 years” and by his own admission he’s either crazy or just loves the music! Not strictly blues, Bobby serves to act as an illustration of some of the trials and tribulations experienced by legendary performers early in their careers, including the influence of the church. B.B. King, Ike Turner, Rufus Thomas, Rosco Gordon, Little Milton, Howlin’ Wolf, Little Milton, Fats Domino and Little Richard are some of the artists featured. Rosco Gordon takes a tour down Beale Street and recalls the past in a timely interview as he passes away at the end of filming, on a tour, in 2002. Memphis had one of the first radio stations on which African Americans appeared as announcers and performers - this proved to be a very lucrative business and a wider audience developed that also included white listeners. Sam Phillips, who is most well known for recording a 19 year-old Elvis, had been recording black artists for some four years before that. Jim Dickinson, musician/producer is also interviewed about the effect the music had on him. When Martin Luther King was assassinated Memphis city officials decided to tear down Beale Street causing an impact on the black history it represented. Broad appeal to white audiences came about in the 1968, culminating in an emotional 95% white audience in front of B.B. King at the Fillmore Auditorium - a new experience for B.B. and one that would mark a change in his audience for good. Ending with a live concert at the WC Handy Awards in 2002, this documentary is sure to inform and inspire.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Pearce, Robert Kenner, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)

results.title: The Soul of a man
results.creator_credit: Wim Wenders, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. In his inimitable interpretation of the documentary Wim Wenders directs in a mixed form of dramatic re-enactment, interviews, clips and footage combined with contemporary musicians performing their own interpretations of some of the songs of the original era. This work explores three particular blues artists and their legacy of great music - Blind Willie Johnson, Skip James and J.B. Lenoir. Beginning in outer space, we learn that on a record sent to represent the human race is a blues song by Blind Willie Johnson. Wenders constructs a narrative to illustrate the possible life and times of Blind Willie, narrated in first person by Laurence Fishburne. Wenders then cuts to a live recording/performance of some of the songs by artists such as Nick Cave and The Bad Seeds, Lou Reed, Beck, Cassandra Wilson, Lucinda Williams and The Jon Spencer Blues Explosion, amongst others, throughout the biographical storytelling. Skip James was another extremely influential artist from the 1920/30s and his story is also re-created - how he won a competition to make a record but never saw any royalty money from it and then left music to start a ministry in the church. Thankfully he was re-discovered in 1965 and some rare live recordings are shown. Also re-discovered for this documentary is footage of the performer and songwriter J.B. Lenoir, seen in his coat-tail costumes, playing guitar and singing songs from his soul. Tragically lost to a car accident, his songs and influence are still felt today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wim Wenders, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)

results.title: Warming by the devil's fire
results.creator_credit: Charles Burnett, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. Kidnapped by Uncle Buddy, on his way to be saved from the devil by being baptised, a young 11 year-old boy gets a life education on exactly what it is he is going to be ‘saved’ from. Through a re-telling of this young boy’s journey travelling the Deep South, his education becomes the viewers’ with a narration (by Carl Lumbly) of the boy as an adult recalling this past he will never forget. The history of the African American musician is his lesson, starting out in New Orleans and the blues music that stemmed from early 1900 to the 1940s turns into, as the director says, a ‘story that gives you the impression of the blues’. Inserted in the ‘educational’ narrative is a combination of archival footage of the period, original performances and stills. The influence of the church and gospel music is covered and the work also includes details of female performers whose powerful music and voices transcend time and place, such as Bessie Smith, Victoria Spivey, Ma Rainey, Dinah Washington and Sister Rosetta Thorpe. Others featured include Willie Dixon, Sonny Boy Williamson, Son House, John Lee Hooker and Muddy Waters amongst many others. Cast includes Tommy Redmond Hicks and Nathaniel Lee Jr. with an original score by Stephen James Taylor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charles Burnett, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)

results.title: Piano blues
results.creator_credit: Clint Eastwood, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. An intimate series of interviews with some of the big names in piano blues music in America with director, and fellow pianist, Clint Eastwood. Starting out with Ray Charles and featuring clips and photographs of musicians of the last century, Eastwood’s journey is sure to inspire a new generation as he asks “Who were your influences…?” Whilst guitar seems to take centre stage in modern blues, it could be argued that it was piano that lead to the popularisation of the form with hit makers such as Ray Charles, Fats Domino and Duke Ellington leading the way. Refreshingly includes some footage and interviews with female musicians. Some of the legends seen performing are: Ray Charles, Dr. John, Fats Domino, Prof. Longhair, Nat King Cole, Dave Brubeck, Marcia Ball, Jay McShann, Art Tatum, Big Joe Turner and Duke Ellington among many others.

results.title: Pearl Harbor = Pearl Harbour
results.creator_credit: Michael Bay, Jerry Bruckheimer and Jerry Bruckheimer Films
results.brief_description: Resoundingly derided drama about the invasion on Pearl Harbor by the Japanese, this film, directed by Michael Bay, nonetheless contains some impressive sequences, mostly the expertly executed and detailed battle scenes. Less engaging is the love triangle between two pilots, and the girl they both fall for. Cast includes Ben Affleck, Josh Hartnett, Kate Beckinsale, Cuba Gooding Jnr, Jon Voight.

results.title: Azumi
results.creator_credit: Ryuhei Kitamura, Mataichiro Yamamoto, Toshiyaki Nakazawa, Sedic International Inc and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: Orphaned as a young girl, Azumi is brought up by a masterly warrior to be a highly skilled, trained assassin. One of a band of children brought up in this manner, as adults the crew are sent off to eliminate corrupt warlords who are preventing peace in the land. In battle Azumi and her group encounter an array of fierce and exotic enemies whilst contending with their internal conflicts. Based on the Manga comic, “Azumi” is great fun with its colourful villains and incessant action sequences; although at times quite cheesy, the over-the-top nature of the director’s aesthetic combines well with his flair for outrageous gore and mordant humour.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ryuhei Kitamura, Mataichiro Yamamoto, Toshiyaki Nakazawa, Sedic International Inc and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha

results.title: In shifting sands: the truth about UNSCOM and the disarming of Iraq
results.creator_credit: Scott Ritter, Alex Cohn and Five Rivers Productions
results.brief_description: Former United Nations weapons inspector Scott Ritter has compiled this series of interviews and footage into an interesting account of events leading up to the invasion of Iraq. The weapons inspectors were sent in on a supposedly non-political mission, their knowledge base being about weapons. Frustration with Iraqi officials denying them access to sites is shown and general dissatisfaction in the pressure brought to bear by politicians who were after a desired outcome. No definitive answers are given but the film provides some insight to the trying process the inspectors were put through. Please note that due to the nature of the original source material, the footage of “In shifting sands” is of a variable standard.
results.title_for_label: In shifting sands: the truth about UNSCOM and the disarming of Iraq

Frustration with Iraqi officials denying them access to sites is shown and general dissatisfaction in the pressure brought to bear by politicians who were after a desired outcome. No definitive answers are given but the film provides some insight to the trying process the inspectors were put through. Please note that due to the nature of the original source material, the footage of “In shifting sands” is of a variable standard.
description_for_label: Former United Nations weapons inspector Scott Ritter has compiled this series of interviews and footage into an interesting account of events leading up to the invasion of Iraq. The weapons inspectors were sent in on a supposedly non-political mission, their knowledge base being about weapons. Frustration with Iraqi officials denying them access to sites is shown and general dissatisfaction in the pressure brought to bear by politicians who were after a desired outcome. No definitive answers are given but the film provides some insight to the trying process the inspectors were put through. Please note that due to the nature of the original source material, the footage of “In shifting sands” is of a variable standard.

results.title: The Grudge 2 = Ju-on 2
results.creator_credit: Takashi Shimizu, Takashige Ichise, Kadokawa Shoten Publishing Company and Nikkatsu Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: In this sequel to “The Grudge”, a Tokyo house has been the site of many strange disappearances. A television crew go to investigate the site, setting off a spate of killings by the evil spirit that dwells there. Although not as well received as “The Grudge” this horror film contains a convoluted narrative, but contains exemplary scares and thrills, fitting for the genre, with a chilling finale. Cast includes: Noriko Sakai, Chiharu Niiyama and Kei Horie.

results.title: Phenomena
results.brief_description: Creepy thriller from horror maestro Dario Argento features a strong performance from a very young Jennifer Connelly as an imperilled schoolgirl (also named Jennifer) who undergoes a series of frightening encounters whilst boarding at a Swiss finishing school. After experiencing nightmares that provide insight into a serial killer’s movements, Jennifer’s talent for communicating with insects links her to bug specialist Dr McGregor, with whom she aims to unmask the murderer. Engaging in the tropes of the genre - and using his trademark gore and gross-out aesthetics - Argento provides an array of thrills, scares and narrative twists all backed by a rock soundtrack. Uncut, uncensored widescreen edition. Also known as “Creepers” (US title).

results.title: Jedda [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Charles Chauvel and Charles Chauvel Productions
results.brief_description:
As Australia’s first feature film with Aboriginal lead roles, Jedda is beloved by many First Peoples. It was one of the first times we saw stories of our people explored and it’s lauded for its representation of “so many Aboriginal men and women, girls and boys on the screen.” But despite being a first for First Peoples representation, Jedda also reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history characterised by formal policies of assimilation and the forced removal of Indigenous children from their families by the government.
The tale of an Aboriginal woman torn between her white upbringing and her heritage, Jedda (Charles Chauvel’s last feature film) is the first Australian-made colour feature and first Australian film nominated for the Cannes Film Festival’s Palme d’Or. It stars Arrernte actress Rosalie Kunoth-Monks (credited as Ngarla Kunoth) as Jedda and Tiwi actor Robert Tudawali as Marbuck. Due to the film’s popularity, and a rising interest in Aboriginal ‘kitsch’ and culture, Kunoth-Monks and Jedda became entwined. But unlike Tudawali, who had other roles, Kunoth-Monks never acted again and became an advocate for Australia’s First Peoples. Cast also includes Betty Suttor, Paul Reynall, George Simpson-Lytle, Tas Fitzer, Wason Byers, Willie Farrar, and Margaret Dingle
